statement.p:
Match the curves in the graph to the following functions:
\amp (a)\;\; y=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^x \amp \amp (b)\;\; y=1^x \amp \amp (c)\;\; y=2^x
\amp (d)\;\; y=2^{-x} \amp \amp (e)\;\; y=3^x

hint.p: Two of the functions are the same.

solution.p: Since 1^x=1 for any x, we see that (b) is just the constant function y=1, so D matches to (b).

Since 2^{-x}=\frac{1}{2^x}=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^x, functions (a) and (d) are the same. This is the only function out of the lot that grows as x\to-\infty and shrinks as x \to \infty, so A matches to (a) and (d).

This leaves B and C to match to (c) and (e). Since 3 \gt 2, when x \gt 0, 3^x \gt 2^x. So, (e) matches to the function that grows more quickly to the right of the x-axis: B matches to (e), and C matches to (c).

statement.p:
The graph below shows an exponential function f(x)=a^x and its derivative f'(x). Choose all the options that describe the constant a.
\amp (a)\;\; a \lt 0\amp \amp (b)\;\;a \gt 0\amp \amp (c)\;\;a \lt 1
\amp (d)\;\;a \gt 1\amp \amp (e)\;\; a \lt e\amp \amp(f)\;\; a \gt e

solution.p: First, let's consider the behaviour of exponential functions a^x based on whether a is greater or less than 1. As we know, \ds\lim_{x\to\infty}a^x =\left\{\begin{array}{ll} \infty & a \gt 1\\ 0&a \lt 1 \end{array}\right. and \ds\lim_{x\to-\infty}a^x=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 0 & a \gt 1\\ \infty&a \lt 1 \end{array}\right.. Our function has \ds\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x)=\infty and \ds\lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x)=0, so we conclude a \gt 1: thus (d) and also (b) hold. (We could have also seen that (b) holds because a^x is defined for all real numbers.)

It remains to decide whether a is greater or less than e. (If a were equal to e, then f'(x) would be the same as f(x).) We saw in the text that \diff{}{x}\{a^x\}=C(a)a^x for the function C(a)=\ds\lim_{h \to 0} \dfrac{a^h-1}{h}. We know that C(e)=1. (Actually, we chose e to be the number that has this property.) From our graph, we see that f'(x) \lt f(x), so C(a) \lt 1=C(e). In other words, \ds\lim_{h \to 0} \dfrac{a^h-1}{h} \lt \ds\lim_{h \to 0} \dfrac{e^h-1}{h}; so, a \lt e. Thus (e) holds.

hint.p: When can you use the power rule?

solution.p: The power rule tells us that \diff{}{x}\{x^n\}=nx^{n-1}. In this equation, the variable is the base, and the exponent is a constant. In the function e^x, it's reversed: the variable is the exponent, and the base it a constant. So, the power rule does not apply.

statement.p: A population of bacteria is described by P(t)=100e^{0.2t}, for 0 \leq t \leq 10. Over this time period, is the population increasing or decreasing?
We will learn more about the uses of exponential functions to describe real-world phenomena in Section.

hint.p: What is the shape of the curve e^{ax}, when a is a positive consant?

solution.p: P(t) is an increasing function over its domain, so the population is increasing.
There are a few ways to see that P(t) is increasing.

What we really care about is whether e^{0.2t} is increasing or decreasing, since an increasing function multiplied by 100 is still an increasing function, and a decreasing function multiplied by 100 is still a decreasing function. Since f(t)=e^t is an increasing function, we can use what we know about graphing functions to see that f(0.2t)=e^{0.2t} is also increasing.

Using the quotient rule,
f'(x)=\frac{2xe^x-2e^x}{4x^2}=\frac{e^x(2x-2)}{4x^2}=\frac{(x-1)e^x}{2x^2}

statement.p: Differentiate f(x)=e^{a+x}, where a is a constant.
For which values of x is the function f(x)=xe^x increasing?

hint.p: Figure out where the derivative is positive.

solution.p:
If the derivative is positive, the function is increasing, so let's start by finding the derivative. We use the product rule (although Question gives a shortcut).
f'(x)&=1\cdot e^x+xe^x=(1+x)e^x
Since e^x is always positive, f'(x) \gt 0 when 1+x \gt 0. So, f(x) is increasing when x \gt -1.

statement.p:
A particle's position is given by
s(t)=t^2e^t.
When is the particle moving in the negative direction?

hint.p: To find the sign of a product, compare the signs of each factor. The function e^t is always positive.

answer.p: When t is in the interval (-2,0).

solution.p:
The question asks when s'(t) is negative. So, we start by differentiating. Using the product rule:
s'(t)&=e^t(t^2+2t)
&=e^t \cdot t(t+2)
e^t is always positive, so s'(t) is negative when t and 2+t have opposite signs. This occurs when -2 \lt t \lt 0.

statement.p: Let g(x)=f(x)e^x, for a differentiable function f(x). Give a simplified formula for g'(x).
Functions of the form g(x) are relatively common. If you remember this formula, you can save yourself some time when you need to differentiate them. We will explore this more in Question, Section.

hint.p: After you differentiate, factor out e^x.

solution.p: Using the product rule, g'(x)=f'(x)e^x+f(x)e^x=[f(x)+f'(x)]e^x

statement.p:
Which of the following functions describe a straight line?
\amp (a)\;\;y=e^{3\log x}+1\amp \amp (b)\;\; 2y+5=e^{3+\log x}\amp \amp(c)\;\; y=e^{2x}+4
\amp(d)\;\; y=e^{\log x}3^e+\log 2

solution.p: We simplify the functions to get a better idea of what's going on.
(a): y=e^{3\log x}+1=\left(e^{\log x}\right)^3+1=x^3+1. This is not a line.
(b): 2y+5=e^{3+\log x}=e^3e^{\log x}=e^3x. Since e^3 is a constant, 2y+5=e^3x is a line.

(c): There isn't a fancy simplification here--this isn't a line. If that isn't a satisfactory answer, we can check: a line is a function with a constant slope. For our function, y'=\diff{}{x}\{e^{2x} +4\}=\diff{}{x}\{e^{2x}\}=\diff{}{x}\left\{(e^x)^2\right\}=2e^xe^x=2e^{2x}. Since the derivative isn't constant, the function isn't a line.
(d): y=e^{\log x}3^e+\log 2=3^e x+\log 2. Since e^3 and \log 2 are constants, this is a line.

statement.p:
Find constants a, b so that the following function is differentiable:
f(x) =\left\{\begin{array}{ll} ax^2 + b & x \le 1\\ e^x & x \gt 1\end{array}\right.

hint.p: In order to be differentiable, a function should be continuous. To determine the differentiability of the function at x=1, use the definition of the derivative.

solution.p: When we say a function is differentiable without specifying a range, we mean that it is differentiable over its domain. The function f(x) is differentiable when x \neq 1 for any values of a and b; it is up to us to figure out which constants make it differentiable when x=1.

In order to be differentiable, a function must be continuous. The definition of continuity tells us that, for f to be continuous at x=1, we need \ds\lim_{x \to 1}f(x)=f(1). From the definition of f, we see f(1)=a+b=\ds\lim_{x \to 1^-}f(x), so we need \ds\lim_{x\to 1^+}f(x)=a+b. Since \ds\lim_{x \to 1^+}f(x)=e^1=e, we specifically need
e=a+b.

So, we also need
\textcolor{red}{2a}=\textcolor{blue}{e}
Therefore, the values of a and b that make f differentiable are a=b=\dfrac{e}{2}.
